title: Beacon Hill Country Park Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Mat Fascione / Beacon Hill Country Park
images.caption: This is the footpath that runs between the Upper and Lower car parks at Beacon Hill.

images.title: Mat Fascione / Welcome to the Labyrinth
images.caption: Welcome to the Labyrinth. A system of raised walkways in the Country Park, a sign near the entrance states: 'This ongoing project was created by Beacon Hill Conservation Volunteers in 2003'

images.title: Mat Fascione / Wood carving at Beacon Hill
images.caption: Wood carving.

images.title: Mat Fascione / Beacon Hill Earthworks
images.caption: Earthworks on the hill. The Bronze Age `Fort` at Beacon Hill is at least 3000 years old.

images.title: Nigel Cox / Beacon Hill toposcope
images.caption: Toposcope. On the eastern end of the Beacon Hill summit, Lincoln is reputedly visible 46 miles or 73 kilometres distant on a clear day.

images.title: DeFacto, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Shepherd and the Ram by Peter Leadbeater. Wooden chainsaw sculpture.

images.title: Paul Buckingham / Summit Rocks, Beacon Hill
images.caption: Summit Rocks. This panorama is looking towards Copt Oak, and the Radio Masts near to there can be clearly seen in the distance.

images.title: Andy Beecroft / View from Beacon Hill
images.caption: View from Beacon Hill

description: Explore 335 acres of mixed woodland, grassland, wildflower meadows and farmland on this country park walk or cycle near Loughborough. At 248m (814 feet), Beacon Hill is the second highest point in Leicestershire and the site of a Bronze Age hill fort. As such there are fabulous views of the Leicestershire countryside. There's a handy toposcope at the hill summit where you can see all the landmarks visible from the viewpoint. The park also has a wooden boardwalk sculpture trail, a maze and a 4.8km cycle track circling the park so you can bring your bike too. Beacon Hill is located a few miles south of Loughborough town centre and very close to the Leicestershire Round walking route.  You could pick up the trail and head to Bradgate Country Park if you wished to extend your walk.
